image.altText: A group of people surrounding a casket being lowered into the ground.

props.synopsis: West Australian teen Cleveland Dodd has been laid to rest, but his family still have questions about the circumstances surrounding his death. Four decades earlier, the relatives of 16-year-old John Pat had similar concerns after the boy died in police custody.

title.children: 'No-one else to blame': What has changed 40 years on from the brutal death of an Aboriginal teen in custody

image.altText: A woman wearing an orange suit smiles with a microphone in front of her.

props.synopsis: Maybe it's the celebrity touch, but the public fascination with Bruce Lehrmann's defamation case has only increased this week, as journalist Lisa Wilkinson was cross-examined by Mr Lehrmann's barrister.

title.children: Lisa Wilkinson's evidence provided compelling viewing as she locked horns with Bruce Lehrmann's lawyers

image.altText: A close up of a smiling Matthew Perry, wearing clear plastic-rimmed glasses, a black suit jacked and a grey v-neck shirt.

props.synopsis: The LA medical examiner says Perry also drowned in "the heated end of his pool", but that it was a secondary factor in his October 28 death, which was deemed an accident.

title.children: Matthew Perry autopsy reveals Friends actor's cause of death

image.altText: A person looks at a packet of chips in a supermarket or convenience store.

props.synopsis: When ultra-processed foods first hit supermarket shelves, people weren't convinced they were real food. Now many Australians depend on them.

title.children: When ultra-processed foods were invented, people didn't want to eat them. Now, we rely on them

image.altText: A mother and daughter look at a water bottle with brown water in it.

props.synopsis: Ingrid and her family can't afford to buy bottled water, so when the taps runs a dirty brown, tainted by iron and manganese, they don't drink it.

title.children: In a community where taps spew 'dark brown' water, the local pub spends hundreds on bottled water — it's a luxury not everyone can afford

image.altText: A close up of Jim speaking in a suit and orange tie outside a building during the day.

props.synopsis: The real political danger — and the opportunity — that now confronts the government is that as nominal wages rise, the very issue that the stage 3 tax cuts were supposed to address is coming into play, writes Laura Tingle.

title.children: The fate of the stage 3 tax cuts could change the 'story' of the government's third budget

image.altText: A composite of three images of men, one of them smiling

props.synopsis: The Israeli military on Friday mistakenly killed three Israeli hostages during its ground operation in the Gaza Strip, military officials say.

title.children: Israeli military says it mistakenly killed three Israeli hostages in Gaza

image.altText: A golden labrador and a black labrador stand on a porch with their noses touching.

props.synopsis: Animal behaviour experts agree that dogs mourn when they lose a companion, but have mixed views on whether being there at the death helps their grieving process.

title.children: Dogs grieve too, so should they be present when their canine companions are put down?

image.altText: Um Ali and her son moving into their new apartment in Australia.

props.synopsis: A young girl has saved up all her pocket money to donate to kids who've just arrived in Australia from war-torn Gaza. She's not alone. Across the country, children have been donating their savings and toys to support families who've just settled in the country.

title.children: Communities donate rent-free homes, toys and everyday essentials to newly arrived Gazan on temporary visas

image.altText: People wait with their luggage while sitting on bench seats at the airport.

props.synopsis: Airlines and popular travel destinations are offering unique solutions to ditching cumbersome luggage in an effort to either reduce their travel footprint or the impact of tourism on local communities. Here are some of them.

title.children: Countries and airlines are looking at luggage solutions. It could offer lessons for the future of travel

image.altText: a large tree that has fallen into a wire fence, crushing it

props.synopsis: A 30-year-old man has died after emergency services found him unconscious near fallen powerlines as dangerous thunderstorms swept across Queensland's south-east.

title.children: Police investigating after man dies in severe south-east Queensland storms

image.altText: Image of a young blond boy wearing a striped rugby shirt while smiling into the camera.

props.synopsis: A teenager from Britain who resurfaced in southern France after disappearing six years ago is expected to return to England over the weekend.

title.children: Boy who was missing for six years will return to Britain, after being found on French motorway

image.altText: Leigh Creighton standing at a lookout with a mountain in the distance behind him.

props.synopsis: Dating is already challenging, but for people like Leigh who live with an intellectual disability, the barriers can be even higher.

title.children: Leigh has been looking for love for over a decade, but says he faces judgement and rejection

image.altText: Artist Mike Parr painting text onto a white gallery wall with black paint, while his eyes are closed.

props.synopsis: Picasso's Guernica is displayed in a gallery devoted to conflict. In time perhaps Mike Parr's work should be seen in that context of war art too: painted "blind", messy and dangerous but holding up a mirror to a brutal conflict that none of us can close our eyes to, writes Virginia Trioli.

title.children: In time perhaps Mike Parr's art should be seen in the same context as Picasso's Guernica

image.altText: A footballer wearing an eye mask kisses a ball.

props.synopsis: Tottenham plays the final half hour of its match against Nottingham Forest with 10 men, but comes away with a 2-0 victory.

title.children: Postecoglou's Spurs make it back-to-back wins after nervous 10-man victory over Nottingham Forest

image.altText: A woman with long black hair leaning against a brick wall

props.synopsis: On top of already painful symptoms, many women with endometriosis from multicultural backgrounds face cultural pressures to start a family after marriage.

title.children: When Harsha told her in-laws she had endometriosis, they told her it was 'a disease made up by doctors who want to make money'

image.altText: An animation of sprinkling flour with images of recipe books and a cake.

props.synopsis: In a world where recipes can be accessed with a keystroke, well-thumbed, old cookbooks can provide more than nostalgia and the comforts of home — they're a snapshot of who we are and where we've come from.

title.children: History, tradition and good taste: Why our treasured old cookbooks still matter today

image.altText: a makeshift toilet in a tin shed with a man holding the door.

props.synopsis: Brandon Hawkins leads the Willigobung RFS brigade in the New South Wales Snowy Valleys, and says his station is woefully unprepared for this year's fire season due to broken and outdated equipment.

title.children: A pipe for a toilet, a duct-taped truck and melted hoses are what stands between residents and bushfires

image.altText: A young woman in Santa hat and swimsuit looks at the ocean under blue skies

props.synopsis: Early modelling indicates Christmas Day will see showers and thunderstorms up and down the eastern seaboard along with a potential cyclone tormenting the northern tropics.

title.children: Christmas Day weather forecast for your city as Jasper threat remains

image.altText: Mitch Marsh's stumps are broken as he completes a drive during a Test.

props.synopsis: The second day in Perth looked to be following a familiar script, with an Australian procession seemingly on the cards. But this Pakistan is made of tougher stuff, and proved it is here to stand up and fight.

title.children: The one ball that flipped the script in Perth as Australia finds out Pakistan is up for the fight

image.altText: A woman sits in an apartment with an open suitcase.

props.synopsis: If you're considering subletting your rental as a holiday home, there are several things to consider.

title.children: Thinking of subletting over the holidays? Here's what you need to know

image.altText: A man sits in the doorway of a tiny home with a cat laying down next to him

props.synopsis: Martin Klussendorf spent nine months building his tiny home. He has enough money to buy a plot of land, but most local laws across Australia won't allow him to set up permanently on it. He believes that should change.

title.children: Tiny-home owner joins call for local governments to relax laws for transient Australians

image.altText: APY ACC gallery in Adelaide

props.synopsis: The artists and manager of an Indigenous art collective accused of inappropriately intervening in Aboriginal art, say the government's failure to close the investigation is causing ongoing trauma to artists and damage to the industry.

title.children: APY Art Collective manager says panel's referral over art interference allegations 'kicks the can down the road'

subjects.title: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Art

image.altText: Four people learning in a science class.

props.synopsis: When Kirsha Kaechele randomly surveyed a group of teenagers about their interests, she was surprised to hear "beauty" topped their lists. It inspired her to build a lab that teaches science through beauty products.

title.children: The 'beauty laboratory' teaching teenagers science by stealth

image.altText: Premier Steven Miles with Deputy Premier Cameron Dick standing behind him

props.synopsis: The next Queensland election is less than a year away and, now he's taken over the top, job Steven Miles is keen to avoid facing the final curtain at the ballot box, writes Rachel Riga.

title.children: He was Palaszczuk's right hand man. As premier, Steven Miles is out to do it his way

image.altText: traditional chinese-style buildings that make up the forbidden city complex covered in snow in a haze

props.synopsis: President Xi Jinping called for "all-out" emergency response efforts as a cold wave froze most of China on Friday, affecting transport and sending hundreds to hospital after a train crash in Beijing.

title.children: Cold wave freezes China, sending hundreds to hospital after Beijing train crash

image.altText: flood waters beneath a street of houses

props.synopsis: A "dog's breakfast" is how a North Queensland councillor has described the Australian Warning System during Ex-Tropical Cyclone Jasper. The government admits it needs fine tuning.

title.children: New warning system leaves cyclone residents panicked, in heightened state of fear

image.altText: A large ship with containers labeled "maersk" stacked on top of it

props.synopsis: Danish shipping company AP Moller-Maersk will pause all container shipments through the Red Sea until further notice, a spokesperson for the company says.

title.children: Maersk pauses Red Sea traffic after Houthi attack

image.altText: A green night parrot on the ground.

props.synopsis: Indigenous rangers manage to record the song of the "extremely secretive" night parrot in a remote part of Western Australia.

title.children: Rare recording of 'mysterious' night parrot captured, described as 'holy grail' of ornithology

image.altText: Two children draw, smiling.

props.synopsis: Families say childhood dementia is underfunded and under-researched and they want greater public awareness to help improve their children's short lives.

title.children: Families say childhood dementia is under-researched, calling for greater awareness to help improve their children's short lives

image.altText: Sydney lawyer Nicholas Stewart stands with his arms crossed against a glass window

props.synopsis: After an 18-month examination into possible gay hate crimes in Sydney, human rights lawyer Nicholas Stewart says what has been uncovered exceeded expectations and should trigger further inquiries or inquests.

title.children: Lawyer's fears 'validated' after spending years advocating for authorities to revisit potential gay hate crimes

image.altText: A man with wearing glasses and white top smiling.

props.synopsis: As the grief from Dr Michael Yung's alleged murder continues to ripple through the community, those who helped him establish a charity in honour of his late wife are determined to continue his dream.

title.children: 'Giving was at the core of who they were': Adelaide doctor's legacy to continue

image.altText: Composite image of Cate Blanchette as Tar, Cillian Murphy from Oppenheimer, a donkey and someone from Asteroid City

props.synopsis: From sweeping epics to kooky indies, the ABC critics pick their top films of the year: How many have you seen?

title.children: Our critics picked these films as their top watches of the year: How many have you seen?
